keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.

The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with the highest death tolls in Veracruz (29), Hidalgo (21), Puebla (13), and Queretaro (1).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and aid to affected areas.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply to about 263,000 affected users.
Approximately 100,000 houses have been impacted, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
President Claudia Sheinbaum highlighted that there were no early meteorological warnings indicating the extreme rainfall intensity, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond led to severe flooding in five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). Over 100,000 homes were affected, with some near rivers completely destroyed. The Mexican military and civil protection agencies deployed thousands of personnel to deliver food, water, and aid, while nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of electricity to about 263,000 affected users. Despite emergency efforts, the lack of early meteorological warnings raises questions about Mexico’s disaster preparedness and alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
